1.text: It is for man to prepare the soul, and for the Lord to govern the tongue.

2.text: All the ways of a man are open to his eyes; the Lord is the one who weighs spirits.

3.text: Open your works to the Lord, and your intentions will be set in order.

4.text: The Lord has wrought all things because of himself. Likewise the impious is for the evil day.

5.text: All the arrogant are an abomination to the Lord. Even if hand will be joined to hand, he is not innocent. The beginning of a good way is to do justice. And this is more acceptable with God than to immolate sacrifices.

6.text: By mercy and truth, iniquity is redeemed. And by the fear of the Lord, one turns away from evil.

7.text: When the ways of man will please the Lord, he will convert even his enemies to peace.

8.text: Better is a little with justice, than many fruits with iniquity.

9.text: The heart of man disposes his way. But it is for Lord to direct his steps.

10.text: Foreknowledge is in the lips of the king. His mouth shall not err in judgment.

11.text: Weights and scales are judgments of the Lord. And all the stones in the bag are his work.

12.text: Those who act impiously are abominable to the king. For the throne is made firm by justice.

13.text: Just lips are the will of kings. He who speaks honestly shall be loved.

14.text: The indignation of a king is a herald of death. And the wise man will appease it.

15.text: In the cheerfulness of the kingâ€™s countenance, there is life. And his clemency is like belated rain.

16.text: Possess wisdom, for it is better than gold. And acquire prudence, for it is more precious than silver.

17.text: The path of the just turns away from evils. He who guards his soul preserves his way.

18.text: Arrogance precedes destruction. And the spirit is exalted before a fall.

19.text: It is better to be humbled with the meek, than to divide spoils with the arrogant.

20.text: The learned in word shall find good things. And whoever hopes in the Lord is blessed.

21.text: Whoever is wise in heart shall be called prudent. And whoever is sweet in eloquence shall attain to what is greater.

22.text: Learning is a fountain of life to one who possesses it. The doctrine of the foolish is senseless.

23.text: The heart of the wise shall instruct his mouth and add grace to his lips.

24.text: Careful words are a honeycomb: sweet to the soul and healthful to the bones.

25.text: There is a way which seems right to a man, and its end result leads to death.

26.text: The soul of the laborer labors for himself, because his mouth has driven him to it.

27.text: The impious man digs up evil, and in his lips is a burning fire.

28.text: A perverse man stirs up lawsuits. And one who is verbose divides leaders.

29.text: A man of iniquity entices his friend, and he leads him along a way that is not good.

30.text: Whoever, with astonished eyes, thinks up depravities, biting his lips, accomplishes evil.

31.text: Old age is a crown of dignity, when it is found in the ways of justice.

32.text: A patient man is better than a strong one. And whoever rules his soul is better than one who assaults cities.

33.text: Lots are cast into the lap, but they are tempered by the Lord.
